title: Legal abortion supported by over 60% of Iowans as midterm election nears
description: A new Iowa Poll shows the majority of Iowans support legal abortion. However, Iowans are more divided when it comes to the "fetal heartbeat” ban.
text_headers:
Iowa Poll: Majority of Iowans support legal abortion. Will it push voters to the polls?
Most Iowans, 61%, say abortion should be legal in most or all cases
‘Fetal heartbeat’ abortion law an emotional sticky point for Iowans, interviews show 
Will abortion rights sway Iowans in the 2022 midterms? 
About this poll
Iowa Poll methodology
text: Legal abortion supported by over 60% of Iowans as midterm election nearsNews lowa Caucuses Sports Opinion Business Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals IOWA POLLIowa Poll: Majority of Iowans support legal abortion. Will it push voters to the polls?Most Iowans, 61%, say abortion should be legal in most or all casesKatie Akin Michaela RammDes Moines Register© Copyright 2022, Des Moines Register and Tribune Co.An overwhelming majority of Iowans want abortion to be legal in the case of rape or incest or to save the pregnant person’s life, a new Des Moines Register/Mediacom Iowa Poll found. Eighty-five percent of Iowans believe abortion should be legal in cases of rape or incest. Even more, 89%, support legal abortion if the pregnant person’s life is in danger. Even among those who say abortion should be illegal in all or most cases, 66% support exceptions for rape or incest and 75% support an exception if the pregnant person’s life is at risk. “You can’t have children dying because someone made them pregnant when they’re not old enough to have a baby, or a mother dying and leaving children at home,” said Carolyn Breen, 72-year-old Republican and poll respondent. “With things like that, there’s got to be a happy medium somewhere.” Breen, who lives in Wall Lake, is a staunch opponent of abortion and plans to vote for Republican candidates in November. But she believes some flexibility is needed in proposed policies, and she said she’s concerned about desperate individuals seeking abortions through unsafe means.  The new poll of 804 adult Iowans, conducted Oct. 9-12 by Selzer & Co., has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. Iowa Poll:Iowa Poll: Chuck Grassley narrowly leads Mike Franken in US Senate raceIt comes just weeks ahead of the Nov. 8 midterm election. Since the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, Republican-led states have passed a flurry of restrictive new laws, and Democrats have framed the election as a referendum on abortion rights. Most Iowans, 61%, say abortion should be legal in most or all cases, while 33% say all or most cases should be illegal. Six percent are unsure. Although abortion is often seen as a partisan issue among elected officials, the Iowa Poll reveals that about a third of Republicans, 34%, support legal abortion in most or all cases. Sixty percent say it should be illegal in most or all cases. Among poll respondents who plan to vote for Gov. Kim Reynolds, an outspoken opponent of abortion, 33% believe it should be legal in all or most cases. The vast majority of Democrats, 91%, and most independents, 66%, favor legal abortion.  At least half of every demographic group supports it as well, with the exception of evangelicals (33% in favor), the poll shows. A huge majority of women favor legal abortion (72%), as do people under age 35 (69%).   ‘Fetal heartbeat’ abortion law an emotional sticky point for Iowans, interviews show  While large shares of Iowans say they support exceptions to abortion bans in cases of rape or incest or when the pregnant person’s life is in danger, they are more divided on how the government should restrict abortion in other circumstances. The split highlights the complex and often conflicting views Iowans hold on abortion. The debate in Iowa centers on the so-called fetal heartbeat abortion ban, a proposal that Reynolds signed into law in 2018 before the courts blocked it. Under that law, abortion would be prohibited when cardiac impulses are detected in an embryo, generally after about six weeks of pregnancy. Following the court’s reversal on Roe v. Wade, Reynolds asked an Iowa district court judge to lift the injunction on the ban, allowing the law to take effect. The Iowa Poll asked Iowans whether they agree or disagree with the statement: “Abortion should be illegal once a so-called fetal heartbeat is detected, about six weeks after conception.” Nearly half of Iowans, 49%, disagree with that idea. Forty-five percent agree with it, and 7% are not sure. That divide appears to have narrowed since the law was first proposed. In September 2018, shortly after the “fetal heartbeat” bill passed the state Legislature, 52% of Iowans said the proposal went too far, while 39% said the law was appropriate for Iowa. In the most recent poll, the majority of Democrats (76%) and independents (52%) say they disagree with the concept of the “fetal heartbeat” law.  Nearly one in four Republicans, 24%, also say they disagree, while 70% agree.  Poll respondent Victor Logan, a Republican, said he agrees with a “fetal heartbeat” ban in principle. However, the 60-year-old insurance broker in Council Bluffs said he does not support implementing the law because he doesn’t believe personal opinions — neither his nor policymakers’ — should play a role in this issue. Instead, Logan, a former social worker, said he believes others “shouldn’t be telling women what to do with their bodies.”  "These situations can be really, really bad, and we can’t make blanket statements,” he said. “No matter how I may feel, the reality is that things are vastly different for the majority of the population. Why should we legislate that?” Medical professionals have said “heartbeat” is a misleading term to describe the stage of development at about six weeks, a time when the embryo's developing heart begins to emit rhythmic electrical impulses. It isn’t until later in the pregnancy — from 17 to 20 weeks — that a fetus develops an actual heartbeat, they say. Medical professionals also have said many women don’t know they are pregnant at six weeks, which could be as little as two weeks after their missed period. Opponents of the ban have criticized the law for this reason, stating it essentially would act as a total ban on abortion. Iowa Poll:Gov. Kim Reynolds earns 52% support, leads Deidre DeJear by 17 points among likely votersStill, many Iowans have been swayed by the idea of a “fetal heartbeat.”   The Iowa Poll found that 25% of Iowans who say all or most abortions should be legal also agree that the procedure should be illegal once the so-called fetal heartbeat is detected.  Poll respondent Jeff Laughlin, an independent in Davenport, believes abortion should be legal in most cases, particularly if it involves cases of rape or incest or to protect the life of the pregnant person. However, the 66-year-old cab driver also supports an abortion restriction once the so-called fetal heartbeat is detected, because “once the heart kicks in, that’s a living person." More:See where Iowa candidates stand on key issues in the 2022 midterm elections“You have to have a reason to have abortion, and not because you don’t want a baby,” Laughlin said. “If you have six kids and don’t want the seventh, that’s not OK.” Rebecca Mothershead, a Democrat and a retired 67-year-old in Sioux City, said she doesn’t support abortion except in cases of rape, incest or if the woman’s life is in danger.  Once an embryo’s cardiac activity can be heard, she said, she thinks the woman is too far along for an abortion — though she added that she sees a ban at 8 weeks of pregnancy as more common sense than a 6-week ban.  “If they didn’t really want to have a baby, they should put it up for adoption,” Mothershead said.  Will abortion rights sway Iowans in the 2022 midterms? Poll respondent Cassandra Walters, a 26-year-old independent, said she leaned toward Republicans in previous elections. But following the repeal of Roe v. Wade and the surge in restrictive abortion laws across the country, she plans to vote for Democrats in November. “Now that the abortion bans are being pushed by these big Republican leaders, and they’re voicing their opinions on the matter — a matter that shouldn’t have been brought back up — weighed me more to look into what Democrats I want to be voting for because my autonomy is at stake,” she said. Walters, a West Des Moines personal trainer, said she voted for Reynolds, but the six-week abortion ban made her lose respect for the governor “as a woman and … as a policymaker.” “I feel like she is unable to see any side of a story that is not her own,” Walters said. More:What to know about Iowa's judicial retention elections in NovemberDemocrats are banking on voters like Walters — people who support abortion rights and reject Republican candidates who would restrict the procedure. Democratic ads and campaign speeches have centered on the issue, framing Republican opponents who oppose exceptions as extreme. Republicans have been on the defense, walking back past statements and accusing Democrats of supporting abortions up until birth. Despite the political fervor over abortion, several Iowa Poll respondents said in interviews that they’re more worried about day-to-day issues, like rising prices, than abortion rights. More:Nearly 90 Iowa candidates told us where they stand on abortion. Here's what we learned:Republican Darlene Edwards, a 79-year-old living in Farragut, thinks abortions should be illegal in almost all cases in Iowa. She supports exceptions to protect the life of the pregnant person, and in some cases of rape or incest. She celebrated when the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.  “I don’t believe in abortion,” the poll respondent said. “It’s against God.” But Edwards said abortion won’t be top of mind when she heads to the polls this November. Instead, she’s worried about the economy and whether schools are teaching about gender identity or “communist, socialist junk.” Poll respondent Trisha Nelsen, a 46-year-old Johnston resident, personally disagrees with abortion — but she wants it to be legal so individuals can make that decision for themselves. More:How to vote in Iowa's 2022 elections for governor, US Senate, state Legislature“My religious belief is that it’s not right,” said Nelsen, a Democrat. “But that’s my religious belief, and I don’t put my religious beliefs on others.” Nelsen, who has disabilities and is seeking work, said her top issues this election are resources for people with disabilities and the economy. She plans to vote for Democrats. “We’re paying a lot more for groceries, we’re paying a lot more for gas,” Nelsen said. “How am I supposed to pay rent, renters’ insurance, all my bills, have a car, fill it up and get to my doctor’s appointments?” A significant proportion of Iowans who say abortion should be legal in most or all cases are planning to vote for Republican candidates — even those leading the effort to make most abortions illegal, according to the poll. Among Iowans who plan to vote for Reynolds, 33% say most or all abortions should be legal. Republican Kyla Menke, a 33-year-old stay-at-home mother, says all abortions should be legal, and she called the six-week law “ridiculous.” “I just don’t feel like somebody should be telling somebody else what to do with their body,” she said. Menke, an Eagle Grove resident, still plans to support Republicans in the midterms, including Reynolds and U.S. Sen. Chuck Grassley. “I think with every candidate, there's going to be pros and there's going to be cons to them being in office,” she said. “And I think that both of them so far have been on top of most of the issues.” Michaela Ramm covers health care for the Des Moines Register. Follow her on Twitter at@katie_akin. Most Iowans support legal abortion but are divided on 'fetal heartbeat’ ban Iowa Poll: Most likely voters support pro-gun constitutional amendment Iowa Poll: Tom Miller leads Brenna Bird in attorney general race Most now view Donald Trump unfavorably, new Iowa Poll finds Iowa Poll: Most say Iowa’s caucuses should stay first in the nationAbout this pollThe Iowa Poll, conducted Oct. 9-12, 2022, for the Des Moines Register and Mediacom by Selzer & Co. of Des Moines, is based on telephone interviews with 804 Iowans ages 18 or older. Interviewers with Quantel Research contacted households with randomly selected landline and cell phone numbers supplied by Dynata. Interviews were administered in English. Responses were adjusted by age, sex, and congressional district to reflect the general population based on recent American Community Survey estimates. Questions based on the sample of 804 Iowa adults have a maximum margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points. Questions based on the subsample of 620 likely voters in the 2022 general election have a maximum margin of error of plus or minus 3.9 percentage points. This means that if this survey were repeated using the same questions and the same methodology, 19 times out of 20, the findings would not vary from the true population value by more than plus or minus 3.5 percentage points or 3.9 percentage points, respectively.
